_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Trecora Hydrocarbons LLC employs approximately 150 people who live and work in the Silsbee, Texas area. In business at the same location since 1955, the company is the producer of high purity solvents which are used by its customers to manufacture such things as expandable polystyrene and polyethylene. These products are then used to manufacture such consumer staples as styrofoam cups and plastics. Trecora is also active in performing tolling work for various companies.

The Risk Management Program requires the development of scenarios for the accidental release of a toxic or flammable chemical. None of the toxic chemicals listed in the regulation is present at Trecora above the threshold quantity so no scenarios have been developed. The worst case scenario for a flammable chemical involved the instantaneous release of approximately 1.8 MM pounds of pentane. The resultant vapor cloud explosion would affect an estimated radius of 1 mile. The alternative case scenario for a flammable chemical involved the release of 2800 pounds per minute of isopentane in a 10 minute time period. The release distance for this scenario is less than 0.1 miles.

The accident prevention measures in place at Trecora include pressure relief to the flare, secondary pressure relief to the atmosphere for storage tanks, dike walls to control spills, remote valves to isolate tanks, a mechanical integrity inspection program, a leak detection and repair program, and 24 hour on-site surveillance.

The flammable regulated substances that are present at Trecora are hydrogen, methane, ethane, ethylene, and propane. The flammable regulated substances that are present at Trecora and above the threshold quantity are isobutane, butane, butene, isopentane, pentane, and 2,2-dimethylpropane.

A release of butane, isopentane, and pentane took place at Trecora in October 2019 from a process storage tank. The root cause of the event was determined to be a violent storm with high winds and massive rainfall over

a short period of time, which impacted tank containment. Trecora worked promptly with 3rd party emergency response organizations and local law enforcement to contain the event and minimize impact.

Trecora acknowledges that a number of PHA updates are outside the 5 year frequency. PSM records were not digitized as ownership transferred. Observations and findings were discovered during a 2022 3rd party PSM Audit. These findings are being actively pursued.

Trecora has an integrated contingency plan. In the event of emergency, E3 Environmental and/or Vortech Contracting will be the response contractor that will be used by Trecora. The Silsbee Fire Department and the Hardin County Local Emergency Planning Commission are also resources which are available.

Trecora understands that no operation can be completely safe. Trecora recognizes that safety is an ongoing endeavor. Continual improvement is essential. Input from employees and from the community are key elements in ensuring that the improvements in safety continue.
